message_text:
<paper>
Paper Title: Adaptive Prescribed-Time Control for a Class of Uncertain Nonlinear Systems
Paper Abstract: This article focuses on the problem of prescribed-time control for a class of uncertain nonlinear systems. First, a prescribed-time stability theorem is proposed by following the adaptive technology for the first time. Based on this theorem, a new state feedback control strategy is put forward by using the backstepping method for high-order nonlinear systems with unknown parameters to ensure the prescribed-time convergence. Moreover, the prescribed-time controller is obtained in the form of continuous time-varying feedback, which can render all system states converge to zero within the prescribed time. It should be noted that the prescribed time is independent of system initial conditions, which means that the prescribed time can be set arbitrarily within the physical limitations. Finally, two simulation examples are provided to illustrate the effectiveness of our proposed algorithm.
</paper>

<paper_classification>
"contribution" = proposes something new (method, technique, dataset, framework, benchmark, etc.)
"survey" = literature review, overview, meta-analysis, position papers (only references existing work)
</paper_classification>

<entity_types>
task      - Problem being solved (image classification, theorem proving, protein folding)
method    - Technique, algorithm, procedure (gradient descent, CRISPR, induction)
data      - Datasets, databases, benchmarks (ImageNet, MNIST, arXiv corpus)
artifact  - Pre-built: trained models, proof libraries (GPT-4, Mathlib, Cas9)
tool      - Software, instruments, platforms (PyTorch, Lean prover, microscope)
concept   - Abstract ideas, theories, frameworks (attention, category theory)
other     - Entities that don't fit above categories
</entity_types>

<relations>
uses     - Anything EXISTING that the paper uses (methods, datasets, tools, concepts, tasks)
proposes - Anything NEW/NOVEL that the paper creates or introduces

VALIDATION REQUIREMENTS:
- ALL papers MUST have at least 1 "uses" (papers always build on existing work)
- CONTRIBUTION papers MUST have at least 1 "proposes" (they must create something new)
</relations>

<output_json>
{
  "paper_type": "contribution" or "survey",
  "triples": [
    {
      "name": "Wikipedia Article Title",
      "relation": "uses|proposes",
      "entity_type": "task|method|data|artifact|tool|concept|other",
      "wikipedia_url": "https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/...",
      "relevance": "Why this matters (1 sentence)"
    }
  ]
}
</output_json>

<YOUR_TODO_LIST>
FIRST, add ALL of these to your todo list with "TodoWrite" tool:

CRITICAL: Todo content must be copied exactly as is written here, with NO CHANGES. These todos are intentionally detailed so that another LLM could read each one without any external context and understand exactly what it has to do.

1. Read ./triples_output.json. Classify paper as "contribution" or "survey". Edit triples_output.json to set paper_type field.

2. List ALL triples EXPLICITLY mentioned in title/abstract. For each, determine entity_type and relation.

3. For each triple: Use WebSearch tool with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] to search "[entity name]" to find the correct Wikipedia article. IMPORTANT: Always include allowed_domains parameter to restrict to English Wikipedia.

4. Edit triples_output.json to add all triples. For each triple:
   - name: Use the Wikipedia article title (e.g., "Gradient descent" not "gradient descent algorithm")
   - relation: how paper relates to entity (uses or proposes)
   - entity_type: one of task, method, data, artifact, tool, concept, other
   - wikipedia_url: The Wikipedia URL from search results (must start with https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/)
   - relevance: 1 sentence explaining why it matters

5. Run validation: python validate_triple_json.py

6. If validation errors: Fix the errors (use WebSearch with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] again if needed for incorrect URLs), edit triples_output.json, and rerun validation. MUST REPEAT until validation passes.

<CRITICAL_WEBSEARCH_INSTRUCTIONS>
When using WebSearch, you MUST use the allowed_domains parameter:
WebSearch(query="[your query]", allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"])

This ensures only English Wikipedia results are returned. Do NOT search without allowed_domains.
</CRITICAL_WEBSEARCH_INSTRUCTIONS>
</YOUR_TODO_LIST>

Begin now.

## Results for "nonlinear systems"

Here's a comprehensive overview of nonlinear systems based on the search results:

### Definition
Nonlinear systems are systems whose behavior is not expressible as a linear function of its descriptors; that is, such systems are not linear. More technically, a nonlinear system is defined as any system that is not linear, that is any system that does not satisfy the superposition principle.

### Key Characteristics
Nonlinear systems exhibit several distinctive properties:

- They do not follow the principle of superposition (linearity and homogeneity). They may have multiple isolated equilibrium points. They may exhibit properties such as limit cycle, bifurcation, chaos.

- Simple nonlinear dynamical systems, including piecewise linear systems, can exhibit strongly unpredictable behavior, which might seem to be random, despite the fact that they are fundamentally deterministic. This unpredictable behavior has been called chaos.

### Mathematical Challenges
One of the greatest difficulties of nonlinear problems is that it is not generally possible to combine known solutions into new solutions. Additionally, methods of solution or analysis are problem dependent.

### Real-World Applications
Nonlinear control theory applies to more real-world systems, because all real control systems are nonlinear.(no content)Examples of nonlinear differential equations are the Navier–Stokes equations in fluid dynamics and the Lotka–Volterra equations in biology.

Links: [{"title":"Control theory - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Control_theory"},{"title":"Perceptual control theory - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Perceptual_control_theory"},{"title":"Social control theory - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Social_control_theory"},{"title":"Control theory (sociology) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Control_theory_(sociology)"},{"title":"Affect control theory - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Affect_control_theory"},{"title":"Closed system (control theory) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Closed_system_(control_theory)"},{"title":"Plant (control theory) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Plant_(control_theory)"},{"title":"Classical control theory - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Classical_control_theory"},{"title":"Compensator (control theory) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Compensator_(control_theory)"},{"title":"Control (optimal control theory) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Control_(optimal_control_theory)"}]

Here are the search results for "control theory":

## Overview

Control theory is a field of control engineering and applied mathematics that deals with the control of dynamical systems.(no content)The aim is to develop a model or algorithm governing the application of system inputs to drive the system to a desired state, while minimizing any delay, overshoot, or steady-state error and ensuring a level of control stability; often with the aim to achieve a degree of optimality.

## How It Works

A controller monitors the controlled process variable (PV), and compares it with the reference or set point (SP). The difference between actual and desired value of the process variable, called the error signal, or SP-PV error, is applied as feedback to generate a control action to bring the controlled process variable to the same value as the set point.

## History

Control theory dates from the 19th century, when the theoretical basis for the operation of governors was first described by James Clerk Maxwell.(no content)Control theory was further advanced by Edward Routh in 1874, Charles Sturm and in 1895, Adolf Hurwitz, who all contributed to the establishment of control stability criteria; and from 1922 onwards, the development of PID control theory by Nicolas Minorsky.

## Applications

Control theory is used in control system engineering to design automation that have revolutionized manufacturing, aircraft, communications and other industries, and created new fields such as robotics.(no content)As the general theory of feedback systems, control theory is useful wherever feedback occurs, making it important to fields like economics, operations research, and the life sciences.

Web search results for query: "state feedback control"

Links: [{"title":"Full state feedback - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Full_state_feedback"},{"title":"Feedback linearization - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Feedback_linearization"},{"title":"State observer - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/State_observer"},{"title":"Controllability - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Controllability"},{"title":"Control theory - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Control_theory"},{"title":"Ackermann's formula - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ackermann's_formula"},{"title":"Linear–quadratic regulator - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Linear–quadratic_regulator"},{"title":"Robust control - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Robust_control"},{"title":"Feed forward (control) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Feed_forward_(control)"},{"title":"Classical control theory - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Classical_control_theory"}]

Here are the search results for state feedback control:

## Overview

Full state feedback (FSF), or pole placement, is a method employed in feedback control system theory to place the closed-loop poles of a plant in predetermined locations in the s-plane.(no content)Placing poles is desirable because the location of the poles corresponds directly to the eigenvalues of the system, which control the characteristics of the response of the system.

## Key Requirements

The system must be considered controllable in order to implement this method.(no content)Complete state controllability describes the ability of an external input (the vector of control variables) to move the internal state of a system from any initial state to any final state in a finite time interval.

## How It Works

Comparing the terms of the characteristic equation with those of the desired characteristic equation yields the values of the feedback matrix K which force the closed-loop eigenvalues to the pole locations specified by the desired characteristic equation.

## Related Concepts

Knowing the system state is necessary to solve many control theory problems; for example, stabilizing a system using state feedback.(no content)The LQR algorithm is essentially an automated way of finding an appropriate state-feedback controller, and it is not uncommon for control engineers to prefer alternative methods, like full state feedback, also known as pole placement, in which there is a clearer relationship between controller parameters and controller behavior.

Links: [{"title":"Stability theory - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Stability_theory"},{"title":"Stable theory - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Stable_theory"},{"title":"Lyapunov stability - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lyapunov_stability"},{"title":"Routh–Hurwitz stability criterion - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Routh–Hurwitz_stability_criterion"},{"title":"Reeb stability theorem - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Reeb_stability_theorem"},{"title":"Stable manifold theorem - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Stable_manifold_theorem"},{"title":"Moser's trick - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Moser's_trick"},{"title":"Stability spectrum - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Stability_spectrum"},{"title":"Routh–Hurwitz theorem - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Routh–Hurwitz_theorem"},{"title":"Center manifold - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Center_manifold"}]

Based on the search results, here's an overview of stability theorems in mathematics:

## General Stability Theory

In mathematics, stability theory addresses the stability of solutions of differential equations and of trajectories of dynamical systems under small perturbations of initial conditions.(no content)Stability theory addresses the following questions: Will a nearby orbit indefinitely stay close to a given orbit? Will it converge to the given orbit?

## Key Stability Theorems

**Hartman–Grobman Theorem**: Asymptotic stability of fixed points of a non-linear system can often be established using the Hartman–Grobman theorem.(no content)At each equilibrium of a smooth dynamical system with an n-dimensional phase space, there is a certain n×n matrix whose eigenvalues characterize the behavior of nearby points, and if all eigenvalues are negative real numbers or complex numbers with negative real parts then the point is a stable attracting fixed point.

**Lyapunov Stability**: A general way to establish Lyapunov stability or asymptotic stability of a dynamical system is by means of Lyapunov functions.

**Routh–Hurwitz Theorem**: The Routh–Hurwitz theorem gives a test to determine whether all roots of a given polynomial lie in the left-half complex plane. Polynomials with this property are called Hurwitz stable polynomials. The Routh–Hurwitz theorem is important in dynamical systems and control theory.

**Stable Manifold Theorem**: In mathematics, the stable manifold theorem is an important result about the structure of the set of orbits approaching a given hyperbolic fixed point. It roughly states that the existence of a local diffeomorphism near a fixed point implies the existence of a local stable center manifold containing that fixed point.

**Reeb Stability Theorem**: In mathematics, Reeb stability theorem, named after Georges Reeb, asserts that if one leaf of a codimension-one foliation is closed and has finite fundamental group, then all the leaves are closed and have finite fundamental group.

Here are the search results for "adaptive control":

## Overview

Adaptive control is the control method used by a controller which must adapt to a controlled system with parameters which vary, or are initially uncertain.(no content)For example, as an aircraft flies, its mass will slowly decrease as a result of fuel consumption; a control law is needed that adapts itself to such changing conditions.

## Key Differences from Other Control Methods

Adaptive control is different from robust control in that it does not need a priori information about the bounds on these uncertain or time-varying parameters; robust control guarantees that if the changes are within given bounds the control law need not be changed, while adaptive control is concerned with control law changing itself.

## Foundation and Methods

The foundation of adaptive control is parameter estimation, which is a branch of system identification.(no content)Common methods of estimation include recursive least squares and gradient descent. Both of these methods provide update laws that are used to modify estimates in real-time (i.e., as the system operates).

## Categories and Approaches

Direct methods are ones wherein the estimated parameters are those directly used in the adaptive controller. In contrast, indirect methods are those in which the estimated parameters are used to calculate required controller parameters. Hybrid methods rely on both estimation of parameters and direct modification of the control law.

## Modern Applications

In recent times, adaptive control has been merged with intelligent techniques such as fuzzy and neural networks to bring forth new concepts such as fuzzy adaptive control.(no content)A particularly successful application of adaptive control has been adaptive flight control.

Links: [{"title":"Backstepping - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Backstepping"},{"title":"Petar V. Kokotovic - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Petar_V._Kokotovic"},{"title":"Talk:Backstepping - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Talk:Backstepping"},{"title":"Control theory - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Control_theory"},{"title":"Backpropagation - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Backpropagation"},{"title":"Exponential backoff - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Exponential_backoff"},{"title":"Adaptive step size - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Adaptive_step_size"},{"title":"Backpressure routing - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Backpressure_routing"},{"title":"One-step method - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/One-step_method"},{"title":"Backtracking - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Backtracking"}]

Based on the search results, here's information about the backstepping method in control:

## Overview

The backstepping approach provides a recursive method for stabilizing the origin of a system in strict-feedback form.(no content)Backstepping is a method of taking a large and ugly nonlinear problem and stripping off all of the trivial layers so that you're left with a simpler system.

## How It Works

The backstepping approach handles systems in strict-feedback form by using a cascaded structure with a feedback-stabilizing control and corresponding Lyapunov function, which can be repeated iteratively to stabilize an entire strict-feedback system. The process follows these steps:

In each step, the smallest "unstabilized" single-step strict-feedback system is isolated. Feedback is used to convert the system into a single-integrator system. The resulting single-integrator system is stabilized. The stabilized system is used as the upper system in the next step.

## Application and Design

The process "steps backward" from x out of the strict-feedback form system until the ultimate control u is designed.(no content)Any system in this special many-integrator strict-feedback form can be feedback stabilized using a straightforward procedure that can even be automated.

## Historical Context

Petar V. Kokotovic has made contributions in the areas of adaptive control, singular perturbation techniques, and nonlinear control especially the backstepping stabilization method.(no content)Backstepping techniques normally take advantage of results based on Lyapunov's theory.

Based on the search results, here's information about the backstepping method in control:

## Overview

The backstepping approach provides a recursive method for stabilizing the origin of a system in strict-feedback form.(no content)Backstepping is a method of taking a large and ugly nonlinear problem and stripping off all of the trivial layers so that you're left with a simpler system.

## How It Works

The backstepping approach handles systems in strict-feedback form by using a cascaded structure with a feedback-stabilizing control and corresponding Lyapunov function, which can be repeated iteratively to stabilize an entire strict-feedback system. The process follows these steps:

In each step, the smallest "unstabilized" single-step strict-feedback system is isolated. Feedback is used to convert the system into a single-integrator system. The resulting single-integrator system is stabilized. The stabilized system is used as the upper system in the next step.

## Application and Design

The process "steps backward" from x out of the strict-feedback form system until the ultimate control u is designed.(no content)Any system in this special many-integrator strict-feedback form can be feedback stabilized using a straightforward procedure that can even be automated.

## Historical Context

Petar V. Kokotovic has made contributions in the areas of adaptive control, singular perturbation techniques, and nonlinear control especially the backstepping stabilization method.(no content)Backstepping techniques normally take advantage of results based on Lyapunov's theory.


REMINDER: You MUST include the sources above in your response to the user using markdown hyperlinks.
